entry.title: Se√±or Snoofioso? Here's why your pet's nicknames are so weird
entry.summary:
What‚Äôs your dog‚Äôs name? Not the name listed on their vet records‚Äîbut the one that slips out when they steal a sock or tilt their head just right.
One Redditor said their pup‚Äôs name spiraled from ‚ÄúBig Stink‚Äù to ‚ÄúStinky Winky,‚Äù ‚ÄúMoo a Wink,‚Äù and eventually ‚ÄúStoop a Wink.‚Äù
These playful nicknames might seem like nonsense, but linguists say they reflect deeper patterns in how humans form bonds, express affection, and play with language. As pets have transitioned from outdoor workers to indoor companions, the way we talk to‚Äîand about‚Äîthem has also changed.
Scientific literature has shown that nicknames are a powerful way humans express affection and form connections. ‚ÄúThe nicknaming of dogs could also be viewed as a form of creative verbal play,‚Äù says Cynthia Gordon, profes‚Ä¶

entry.title: A practical guide to traveling in Vietnam
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The frenetic pace of Vietnam‚Äôs cities combined with the cultural nuances of this Southeast Asian country can be a lot for travellers to take in. Yet it‚Äôs not a difficult place to navigate ‚Äî as long as you do a bit of forward planning. Transport is visitor-friendly and plentiful, and locals are usually happy to help travellers get their bearings. Follow their lead, and you‚Äôll soon catch your stride.
Many Vietnamese people speak at least some English, particularly in big cities, but this becomes less so the further you get into the countryside. Due to past colonial influence, English and French are more widely spoken in the south than the north, but people who work in traveller-facing businesses are likely to spea‚Ä¶

entry.title: The story behind Caesar salad
entry.summary:
At Restaurante Caesar's, the Caesar salad is always made tableside, showcasing the freshness of the ingredients, and adding dramatics to the diner‚Äôs experience. Caesar salad celebrates its 101st birthday in July 2025. We look at the origins of the popular dish ‚Äî surprisingly, it doesn‚Äôt involve a certain Roman emperor.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Crisp, fresh and satisfying, Caesar salad is a dish that‚Äôs conquered dining outlets the world over, from your neighbourhood bistro and Pret A Manger to Michelin-starred marvels like Osteria Mozza in Los Angeles. While mayonnaise-heavy iterations haunt room-service menus in hotels far and wide, Caesar salad purists live and breathe its original recipe: whole romaine lettuce leaves, crunchy garlic ‚Ä¶

entry.title: What everyone gets wrong about the worst shark attack in history
entry.summary:
"The shark comes to the nearest man and that man he'd start poundin' and hollerin' and screamin' and sometimes the shark go away. Sometimes he wouldn‚Äôt go away."
Robert Shaw‚Äôs iconic monologue as shark hunter Quint in Jaws captured the horror of the day 80 years ago when sharks descended on the crew of the U.S.S. Indianapolis after the vessel was sunk by Japanese torpedoes during World War II. Thanks to the fame of the movie, that speech propelled the worst shark attack in history into public lore.
(Martha‚Äôs Vineyard locals reflect on the legacy of 'Jaws' 50 years later.)
But his speech had some critical errors. Many retellings focus on the sharks mercilessly picking off the survivors, but the terror of that day in July 1945 was ‚Äúmuch more than just a shark story,‚Äù says Lynn‚Ä¶

entry.title: This ancient city is a vegetarian traveler's dream
entry.summary:
Kutaisi, a UNESCO City of Literature, is also one of the world's oldest continuously inhabited areas. In Kutaisi, Georgia, Imeretians still forage in nature for the ingredients that compose their colorful, vegetarian-friendly fare. These restaurants and dishes are ones locals return to time and time again.
Imereti's capital still smells like the Silk Road; mid-Autumn air thickens with cheerful chatter and agreeable odors as locals nimbly navigate Kutaisi's Green Bazaar. They chomp churchkhela (strings of walnuts coated in grape-juice caramel), pivot between spice stalls armed by affable matriarchs, and accept samples from spongy wheels of Imeruli cheese.
In the background, the soft soundtrack of the Rioni River interplays with the bazaar bustle. The Caucasus Mountains, Co‚Ä¶

entry.title: This was a hotspot for great white sharks‚Äîthen they vanished
entry.summary:
Built like a torpedo with rows of terrifying 2.5-inch teeth, the world‚Äôs largest predatory shark is an intimidating sight. So intimidating that some might think an ocean without great white sharks (Carcharodon carcharias) would be a good thing. But their loss causes a ripple effect that transforms the entire ecosystem.
A new study in Frontiers in Marine Science shows what happens when sharks vanish. Seal Island, off South Africa's False Bay was once a great white hotspot‚Äîone of the few places on Earth where the sharks could be seen surging out of the water to capture prey.
‚ÄúIt was air Jaws,‚Äù says marine ecologist Neil Hammerschlag, executive director of the Shark Research Foundation Inc. and a coauthor on the new study. ‚ÄúI don't think there's anything more remarkable in nature th‚Ä¶

entry.title: The unexpected natural wonders near America's busiest airports
entry.summary:
Air travelers with an extended layover at Washington Dulles International Airport can go hiking at Great Falls Park in Virginia. Long layover? Flight delay? These nine urban hiking trails‚Äîfrom a bamboo forest to a wildlife refuge‚Äîare all within 15 miles of major U.S. airport hubs.
Flight delays at America‚Äôs major airports, once a source of anxiety, now represent opportunities for unexpected adventures. Some travelers secretly hope for a delay that provides a chance to step beyond the terminal and discover the natural wonders, such as a hiking trek through bamboo forests near¬†Atlanta¬†or a journey through a wildlife refuge in¬†Denver.
‚ÄúIn difficult moments, nature is scientifically proven to bring us peace,‚Äù said Dan Lambe, chief executive of the¬†Arbor Day Foundation. ‚ÄúResearch s‚Ä¶

entry.title: The wild is a sanctuary
entry.summary: Bend, Oregon sits at the edge of the state‚Äôs high desert, where Ponderosa pine forests meet volcanic buttes, ancient lava flows, and the vast, open spaces of the Great Basin. The elevation shifts quickly here. One moment you‚Äôre walking through sagebrush and basalt, the next you‚Äôre standing in alpine meadows beneath snow-dusted peaks. It‚Äôs a landscape of contrasts and one I keep returning to when I need to reconnect with nature, with creativity, and with stillness. Capturing the Wild with Photographer Jody MacDonaldNational Geographic photographer Jody MacDonald shares what the wild means to her: "I‚Äôve spent most of my life chasing wild, remote places. The wilderness isn‚Äôt just an escape; it‚Äôs a return to something essential. In one week, I found sanctuary in the silence of a glassy la‚Ä¶

entry.title: Shelter and safety elude Afghan women returnees from Iran and Pakistan
entry.summary: As returns of Afghan refugees and those living in refugee-like conditions from Iran and Pakistan increase ‚Äì many forcibly ‚Äì women and girls are arriving in a country where their rights, safety, and futures face severe threats, according to a new UN-led report.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN Human Rights Council hears grim updates on Ukraine, Gaza and global racism
entry.summary: The UN Human Rights Council on Thursday heard sobering briefings on the human rights situations in Ukraine and Gaza, along with a call to confront structural racism and intersectional discrimination worldwide.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN chief ‚Äòappalled‚Äô by worsening Gaza crisis as civilians face displacement, aid blockades
entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General is ‚Äúappalled‚Äù by the deepening humanitarian crisis in Gaza, as civilians face yet another wave of mass displacement with few safe places to go.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Landless and locked out: Young farmers struggle for a future
entry.summary: Agricultural land is more than just a resource to produce food ‚Äì for many older adults around the world, a land deed is the only safety net they have as they enter their old age. As a result, they hold onto it tightly.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Chile and Argentina among coldest places on Earth as polar anticyclone grips region
entry.summary: Temperatures across lower South America have plummeted ‚Äì falling as low as -15¬∞ Celsius or 5¬∞ Fahrenheit in some places ‚Äì as a rare polar cold wave grips the region, the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) reported on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: With sustainable development under threat, Sevilla summit rekindles hope and unity
entry.summary: The landmark Financing for Development conference in Sevilla has concluded with a renewed sense of resolve and a focus on action that can change lives worldwide, according to UN Deputy Secretary-General Amina Mohammed.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: The Sevilla Commitment: A vital step to rebuild trust in global cooperation
entry.summary: Civil society organisations have welcomed the consensus reached at the landmark sustainable development conference concluding this Thursday in Seville, while cautioning that real progress will depend on sustained action.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Who decides to run a marathon in their 70s? These legends
entry.summary:
Science tells us that a marathon runner‚Äôs peak performance years are between ages 25 and 35. But that doesn‚Äôt mean they‚Äôre your best years. Take it from a dozen awe-inspiring runners, all 70 and over, who we caught up with after they crossed the finish line (still flush with joy!) of this year‚Äôs Boston Marathon.
Some have been running for decades; others took it up later in life. All are in elite company: Runners over 65 made up fewer than 3 percent of all marathon participants in 2023, according to the most recent numbers from the nonprofit group Running USA. And runners over 75? Not quite .3 percent. So what keeps some of the world‚Äôs most inspiring amateur athletes committed after a whole lot of years, miles, and worn-out trainers? Good health, sure. But also clarity and camaraderie‚Ä¶

entry.title: Types of deadlines illustrated from beginning to end
entry.summary: Some deadlines come unexpected, some come staggered, and some come on a fixed‚Ä¶ Tags: deadline, Harriet Hand, illustration, Keri Facer

entry.title: This dessert sparked an international rivalry‚Äîhere's why
entry.summary:
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
Sweet as it tastes, this much-loved dessert has a bitter history. As is the case with both hummus and hamburgers, the pavlova‚Äôs birthplace is hotly disputed, with Australia and New Zealand each claiming credit for the idea of crowning towers of billowing meringue with clouds of snowy cream and tumbling fruit.
Regular shots are fired back and forth across the Tasman Sea, most recently when a Kiwi energy company ‚Äòdeclared war‚Äô by installing an advert at Auckland Airport baggage reclaim stating: ‚ÄòHome is where the pavlova was really created‚Äô. Reactions on the other side of ‚Äòthe ditch‚Äô were outraged: ‚ÄòNice of them to promote tourism to Australia‚Äô was one online comment.
The feud goes all the way to the top, as the‚Ä¶

entry.title: Your favorite Fourth of July foods were invented by immigrants
entry.summary:
Hamburgers are one of the main staples found at Independence Day cookouts across America‚Äîbut they actually hail from Germany. Foods like hot dogs, hamburgers, and potato salad have become menu essentials at Independence Day cookouts across the country‚Äîbut their origins actually hail from all around the world.
On a typical red-and-white checkered Fourth of July picnic table, you‚Äôll find everything from a juicy burger and a charred hot dog to piles of potato salad and seemingly endless cans of beer‚Äîit really doesn‚Äôt get more all-American.
Unsurprisingly, the foods we eat to celebrate our country's independence came to us from all over the world. In fact, none of America‚Äôs traditional cookout foods have much to do with the country‚Äôs very first birthday in 1777, a year after the ‚Ä¶

entry.title: 8 must-do adventures in Namibia
entry.summary:
Hiking the impressive orange dunes in Sossusvlei is just one not-to-be-missed experience when visiting Namibia‚Äîand there‚Äôs so much more to see and do. Hike massive sand dunes, sleep under the stars, and enjoy world-class wildlife watching in Namibia.
Namibia is a southwestern African nation roughly twice the size of California, known for having the¬†world‚Äôs oldest desert. The Namib Desert is the scene for many of Namibia‚Äôs must-do adventures, from hiking up Sossusvlei‚Äôs distinctive red and orange dunes at sunrise to spending days exploring the Tok Tokkie Trails on foot.
Despite the harsh desert conditions, Namibia offers abundant wildlife viewing opportunities. Watch elephants, giraffes, zebras, lions, wildebeests, oryx, and other animals congregate at watering holes in‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to stay safe if you're swimming with sharks
entry.summary:
Host Bertie Gregory filming a ragged tooth shark underwater. "Sharks Up Close With Bertie Gregory" premieres on National Geographic on July 5. Although sharks aren‚Äôt the mindless man-eaters they are sometimes made out to be, experts know that staying safe involves skill, knowledge, and practice.
Slashing teeth, lifeless eyes, and a taste for human flesh‚Äîthat's what most movies might have us believe is typical shark behavior. But what is it really like to be in the water with these apex predators?
Sharks have been on Earth for longer than trees, and there are more than 500 species‚Äîfrom the infamous great white and iconic hammerhead to the gentle whale shark and pocket-sized dwarf lanternshark.
(This was the best place on Earth to see great white sharks‚Äîthen they vanished.)‚Ä¶

entry.title: What lies beneath Hitler‚Äôs war lair?
entry.summary:
The floor under Hermann G√∂ring‚Äôs residence at the Wolf‚Äôs Lair, Hitler‚Äôs secret military headquarters on the Eastern Front, revealed the human remains of five individuals, including this adult (above). While police estimate the burials pre-date WWII, others suggest they may be victims of Nazi crimes or the subsequent Soviet army. Researchers are trying to solve the mystery of human remains uncovered at the Wolf‚Äôs Lair, the Nazi headquarters turned tourist attraction.
Amateur archaeologists in Poland recently unearthed five human skeletons‚Äîeach missing hands or feet‚Äîfrom Hitler‚Äôs Wolf‚Äôs Lair, or Wolfsschanze, near the town of Kƒôtrzyn in northeast Poland.
The macabre discovery was made beneath a house once occupied by Hermann G√∂ring. The Nazi field marshal was second-in-command o‚Ä¶

entry.title: Could T. rex swim? Kinda
entry.summary: Despite what's depicted in movies and books, the real Tyrannosaurus rex was likely an awkward swimmer at best.  Evidence suggests dinosaurs like tyrannosaurs were probably best suited to a version of the doggy paddle. When Michael Crichton released the novel Jurassic Park in 1990, he included a terrifying chase through one of the park‚Äôs ponds. Fictional paleontologist Alan Grant, looking after kids Lex and Tim, tries to sneak by a dozing Tyrannosaurus rex and motor across a lake away from the dinosaur. The T. rex follows, swimming after them like ‚Äúthe biggest crocodile in the world.‚Äù The scene stood out so much that it‚Äôs been revamped for the new movie Jurassic World: Rebirth. But while tyrannosaurs might swim in movies and books, could they swim in real life? ‚Ä¶

entry.title: What Norway's midnight sun season is like‚Äîin pictures
entry.summary: This story was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK). undefined undefined To the north of Sunnfjord, the port town of √Ölesund stands out for its quiet elegance, its facades marked by art nouveau curves and carved stone details. Its centre was completely destroyed by fire in 1904 and rebuilt with great care over three years. Today, √Ölesund seems to move at its own pace. Fishing boats dock early, and the morning‚Äôs catch often ends up on a lunch plate just hours later. undefined undefined There are special properties in the fjords, too, including Union √òye, a hotel in Norway‚Äôs Sunnm√∏re Alps. Dating back to 1891, it has hosted a distinguished cast of characters, including German kaiser Wilhelm II and English author Sir Arthur Conan Doyle. Today, guests can enjoy a spell in the floating sauna while gazing out at the magnificent scenery of Norangsfjorden, before leaping into its cold waters. Published in the July/August 2025 issue of National Geographic Traveller (UK). To subscribe to¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK) magazine click here. (Available in select countries only).

entry.title: The wild is a playground
entry.summary:
There‚Äôs a misconception that play is frivolous. That it‚Äôs something you grow out of when you get older and life gets more serious. But in the wild, play is essential. It‚Äôs how we learn, how we adapt, how we connect with something far greater than ourselves. And for me, the wilderness has always been my playground not in the sense of ease or safety, but in the freedom it gives me to move, to test my limits, and to create without constraint.¬†
That‚Äôs exactly what brought me to the wilderness around Bend, Oregon. Capturing the Wild with Photographer Jody MacDonaldNational Geographic photographer Jody MacDonald shares what the wild means to her: "I‚Äôve spent most of my life chasing wild, remote places. The wilderness isn‚Äôt just an escape; it‚Äôs a return to something essential. In one we‚Ä¶

entry.title: This is the face of an ancient Egyptian who lived 4,500 years ago
entry.summary:
This facial reconstruction of an ancient Egyptian whose genome was sequenced was based off a 3D-scan of the skull. Scientists have for the first time sequenced the most complete and oldest ancient Egyptian genome ever found‚Äîunlocking new secrets from the Old Kingdom.
  Sealed in a ceramic funerary pot, knees curled to his chin, the Egyptian skeleton lay undisturbed for thousands of years. In 1902, British archaeologists excavated him from his tomb carved into a limestone hillside in the Nuwayrat necropolis, more than 150 miles south of Cairo. While the pharaohs of his time built colossal monuments like the Great Pyramid of Giza, this man, likely a potter who lived 4,500 to 4,800 years ago, left behind a different kind of legacy: his exceptionally well-preserved DNA.¬† S‚Ä¶

entry.title: Here‚Äôs why you should visit Nashville in 2025
entry.summary:
You won't have to look far for live music on Broadway in Nashville. The Grand Ole Opry is celebrating its 100th anniversary all year‚Äîbut that‚Äôs not the only reason to visit. From hot chicken to Tennessee whiskey to Taylor Swift‚Äôs tour bus, here‚Äôs why Music City is the place to be.
Nashville is seeing a surge in tourism as a major stop in the Americana Music Triangle. Plus, with the Grand Ole Opry‚Äôs 100th anniversary, 2025 FIFA Club World Cup matches, and new flight routes from Vancouver, Orlando, Palm Beach, Indianapolis and beyond, 2025 is the year to visit Nashville.
You don‚Äôt have to be a country music fan to know (and love) the Grand Ole Opry. This iconic music venue is celebrating Opry 100 all year with special events and performances. Tour the museum during the day, an‚Ä¶

entry.title: A last glimpse inside the world‚Äôs vanishing cave societies
entry.summary:
Nearly a decade ago,¬†documentary photographer and National Geographic Explorer Tamara Merino was driving a camper van through the hot and seemingly desolate expanse of Australia‚Äôs Simpson Desert, when one of her tires blew out. The nearly 70,000 square miles of barren red dunes are not a place you want to have car trouble; summer temperatures push into the 120s, and water is scarce. Merino coaxed her van down the road and began to see signs of a town. But there was no one in sight, and the few buildings felt abandoned. Wandering the streets, she spotted a rudimentary metal cross on a hilltop. She scrambled up to take a look and found that a wide courtyard opened up below, forming the facade of an underground Orthodox church.
Merino soon discovered that she was in an opal mining ou‚Ä¶

entry.title: What are hurricanes, typhoons, and cyclones?
entry.summary:
The Louisiana town of Cameron suffered major damage and flooding during Hurricane Laura in August 2020. Coastal areas like this can be devastated by hurricane winds and storm surging. Hurricanes are getting wetter, faster, and fueled by climate change. Here's what causes them‚Äîand why they're becoming so much more destructive.
Hurricanes combine unyielding winds and torrential rain to create some of Earth‚Äôs most powerful storms. When these storms near land, wind can cause devastating damage, even spawning tornadoes. But the bigger danger is rain, which can cause catastrophic, and often deadly, flooding.
These storms gain energy from warm water and its winds whirl in a characteristic circular motion. Tropical storms are named once winds pass 39 miles per hour, and are deemed hur‚Ä¶

entry.title: Gaza: Access to key water facility in Khan Younis disrupted, UN reports
entry.summary: A key water reservoir serving Khan Younis in southern Gaza has become inaccessible following new Israeli displacement orders, sparking fears of a collapse in the city‚Äôs water distribution network and worsening already dire humanitarian conditions, the United Nations warned on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Adhering to bans on mines only in peace time will not work: UN rights chief
entry.summary: The UN‚Äôs top human rights official on Wednesday expressed grave alarm that six European countries are either in the process of or are considering withdrawing from the international treaty prohibiting anti-personnel mines.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Space is not the final frontier ‚Äì it is the foundation of our future: UN deputy chief
entry.summary: Space technologies are no longer a distant frontier but a critical foundation for daily life and global development, the UN Deputy Secretary-General said on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: INTERVIEW: Sevilla ‚Äòa critical test‚Äô of multilateralism
entry.summary: Nations taking part in a flagship UN conference have pledged to address the debt crisis in the Global South and boost sustainable development. However, the real test will be whether or not these commitments will be translated into action.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Haitian capital ‚Äòparalysed and isolated‚Äô by gang violence, Security Council hears
entry.summary: More than 1.3 million people have been displaced in Haiti as surging gang violence, lawlessness, and impunity expose the population ‚Äì especially women and girls ‚Äì to heightened risks of exploitation and sexual violence.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sevilla: Without sustainable development, there is neither hope nor security
entry.summary: A senior UN official has told UN News that the global development challenge is not lack of money, but how to align public and private capital flows. The Sevilla Agreement adopted this week, sets out a roadmap for all UN Member States ‚Äî except the US which pulled out earlier this month ‚Äî with the aim of mobilizing that capital.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Drowning in debt: New forum in Sevilla offers borrowers chance to rebalance the books
entry.summary: A new mechanism offering debt-distressed countries a way to coordinate action and amplify their voice in the global financial system, has been launched at the UN‚Äôs pivotal sustainable development conference in Sevilla.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Rating all the U.S. airports
entry.summary: There are great airports and there are really bad ones. Which one you‚Ä¶ Tags: airports, ranking, Washington Post

entry.title: Uncovering the Hidden Environmental Impact of an Industrial-scale Hog Farm
entry.summary: An award-winning project exposed how a US-governor's pig farming company polluted groundwater, revealing issues of political influence and regulatory neglect.

entry.title: Ticks are taking over city parks. Here's how to avoid them.
entry.summary: Lone star ticks (Amblyomma americanum) like the one pictured here were historically concentrated in the southeastern and south-central United States. But experts say they're creeping into unexpected new territories‚Äîincluding northern cities. It‚Äôs not just the hiking trail where you need to worry about ticks. These arthropods are now a problem in major cities‚Äîand they've brought disease with them. In the compact backyards of Staten Island, Maria Diuk-Wasser was surprised by what she saw. Ticks‚Äîand lots of them‚Äînestled in wood piles, between leaves, and unde‚Ä¶

entry.title: After 41 years in captivity, this sea turtle is swimming home
entry.summary:
The waves were rough on the morning of April 11, but Jorge didn‚Äôt hesitate. With steady strokes, the 220-pound sea turtle dove into the Atlantic Ocean‚Äîhis first swim in open water in 40 years. https://interactives.natgeofe.com/high-touch/nganimals-2506-Turtle-tracking-map/builds/main/html/_graphic.html After spending more than half his life in a shallow aquarium tank in Mendoza, Argentina, hundreds of miles away from the ocean, Jorge is doing what once seemed impossible: He has relearned his natural instincts as he makes his way to the warm waters of Praia do Forte in northern Brazil‚Äîthe place he once called home.
Watching Jorge‚Äôs remarkable journey from afar is Mariela Dassis, a researcher at the National University of Mar del Plata who is in charge of his satellite monitor‚Ä¶

entry.title: Ready to unwind after Pride? Try these relaxing LGBTQ+-friendly getaways
entry.summary:
From the first Pride‚Äîa bold blend of protest and celebration held in New York on June 28, 1970, to mark the anniversary of the Stonewall Uprising‚Äîto today‚Äôs vibrant festivities, Pride Month continues to be a powerful time for the LGBTQ+ community. As a gay man, frequent traveler, and co-author of the book Out in the World from National Geographic, I‚Äôm always moved by the global expressions of unity, identity, and visibility that define this season.
Pride Month is also one of the busiest times of the year. After the parades, marches, drag shows, and community events, many participants are ready for a break. Here are a few LGBTQ+-friendly destinations where you can relax, recharge, and continue celebrating who you are.
An artists‚Äô enclave in Western Massachusetts‚Äîthe first U.‚Ä¶

entry.title: Who was Hedy Lamarr? The Hollywood star who helped invent Wi-Fi
entry.summary:
Bob Cranston and Hedy Lamarr work together in the One and Three Color Studio in 1940. Lamarr was a star in 1940s Hollywood while simultaneously inventing frequency hopping. As an actress, she was known as the ‚Äúmost beautiful woman in the world‚Äù during the 1940s. Lamarr was also a technological genius whose inventions helped support the Allies during WWII.
As the world marched toward the second catastrophic world war, film legend Hedy Lamarr posed for publicity photographs and played femmes fatales on the silver screen. But her day job wasn‚Äôt always top of mind for the actress, one of the biggest names of Hollywood‚Äôs Golden Age.¬†
Lamarr was a technological genius and as she stole Hollywood‚Äôs heart in the 1940s, she was busy dreaming up an invention she hoped could help her ado‚Ä¶

entry.title: The wild is a proving ground
entry.summary:
Located at the intersection of two major ecological zones‚Äîthe eastern slopes of the Cascade Range and the western edge of the High Desert, Bend, Oregon offers an unusually diverse environment for challenging yourself in the outdoors. The region is characterized by a combination of alpine forests, volcanic rock fields, sagebrush steppe, and glacial rivers, often within a 30-mile radius. This geological and ecological diversity makes it one of the most varied outdoor recreation areas in the Pacific Northwest.
The terrain in and around Bend presents a range of challenges that attract climbers, mountain bikers, trail runners, and endurance athletes. Areas like Smith Rock State Park, composed of volcanic rock and basalt cliffs, offer technical climbing routes. Just to the west, trail netwo‚Ä¶

Why wolf poaching is on the rise in the U.S.
entry.summary:
A gray wolf runs in Grand Teton National Park in Wyoming. While it's legal to kill wolves in most parts of the state, they're mostly protected in Oregon and Washington. Wolf poaching is on the rise; the perpetrators are hardly ever found.
 
In a small town in Oregon when a father wolf went missing recently, no details were available about his death. All that‚Äôs known is that someone killed him, and, based on previous¬†cases,¬†it‚Äôs¬†unlikely that the poacher will be apprehended.¬†¬†¬† After being hunted to eradication in Washington and Oregon in the 1930s and 1940s, the gray wolf‚Äôs recovery in these states has been slow. And decades after reintroductions and on-and-off federal protections, there are only about 430 individuals in both states combined. Now, they face anothe‚Ä¶

entry.title: 6 hydration myths that could be hurting your health
entry.summary:
You don‚Äôt have to feel thirsty to be dehydrated. Experts say common myths about hydration can keep people from getting the fluids they need. Think you need 8 cups of water a day? Or that coffee dehydrates you? Experts debunk the most common misconceptions about staying hydrated.
Even though water is the most abundant substance in the human body, it doesn‚Äôt always get the respect it deserves. Nearly half of adults in the U.S. consume less than the recommended amount of water per day, according to a 2023 CivicScience poll of nearly 2,861 people. That‚Äôs a problem‚Äîbecause staying well hydrated is one of the simplest and most powerful ways to support your health.
For starters, it‚Äôs essential for body temperature regulation, joint lubrication, digestion, detoxification, nutrient tra‚Ä¶

entry.title: Where to travel in August
entry.summary:
August is dry season in Ecuador, making for great jungle hikes and wildlife watching opportunities. Expectations and temperatures run high in August. From far-flung Ecuadorian escapes to island-hopping in Scotland, here are some of the destinations worthy of your attention this summer.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Travel in August is all about being canny. It‚Äôs a prime time to be in Europe but you need to be nimble to avoid the crowds and escalating prices across the Med and beaches radiating beyond. It's worth thinking of alternatives if you want more than a packed fly-and-flop beach break or an overheated European city visit where half the venues are closed for the summer.
August is a great time for families to head to far flung des‚Ä¶

entry.title: General Assembly approves $5.4 billion UN peacekeeping budget for 2025-2026
entry.summary: The General Assembly on Monday approved a $5.38 billion budget for UN peacekeeping operations for the 2025-2026 fiscal year, down slightly from the previous year, as delegates wrapped up weeks of negotiations amid warnings about persistent funding challenges.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: Families deprived of the means for survival, humanitarians warn
entry.summary: The United Nations on Tuesday reported that humanitarian operations in Gaza are facing escalating strain, as ongoing fuel shortages, access restrictions and military activity continue to undermine aid delivery and essential services.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan: UN warns of soaring displacement and looming floods
entry.summary: UN humanitarians on Tuesday sounded the alarm over worsening humanitarian conditions in Sudan, as escalating violence continues to displace civilians and the rising risk of severe flooding during the current rainy season.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Iran crisis: UN stays and delivers
entry.summary: A clearer picture of needs across Iran is beginning to emerge after the conflict this month with Israel, which left hundreds dead, several hospitals hit and a spike in Afghan refugees returning home, the UN‚Äôs top official in Tehran said on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Children‚Äôs lives ‚Äòturned upside down‚Äô by wars across Middle East, North Africa, warns UNICEF
entry.summary: Conflicts in the Middle East and North Africa in the last two years reportedly killed, maimed, or displaced over 12 million children across the region, according to the UN Children‚Äôs Fund (UNICEF).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: ‚ÄòThe margins of the budget‚Äô: Gender equality in developing countries underfunded by $420 billion annually
entry.summary: Developing countries currently face a staggering $420 billion annual gap in the funding needed to achieve gender equality, UN Women estimates. This gap means that programmes and services for women and girls are chronically underfunded.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: 50 years of CITES: Shielding wildlife from trade-driven extinction
entry.summary: The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) marks 50 years since it entered into force on Tuesday, celebrating five decades of protecting endangered wildlife from overexploitation through international trade.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Spain and Brazil push global action to tax the super-rich and curb inequality
entry.summary: Spain and Brazil have launched a joint initiative to promote a higher tax take from the super-rich worldwide, aiming to tackle soaring inequality by ensuring those with the most, pay their fair share.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Northern hemisphere heatwave underscores value of early-warning alerts
entry.summary: The blistering early-summer heatwave that‚Äôs brought life-threatening temperatures across much of the northern hemisphere is a worrying sign of things to come, UN weather experts said on Tuesday.

entry.title: Eating disorders are on the rise in menopausal women
entry.summary:
Experts say that eating disorders are more common during menopause than you might think‚Äîa result of hormonal changes as well as an array of societal pressures and unique midlife challenges. Long overlooked in women 40 and older, midlife eating disorders are going up. Eating disorder specialists cite hormonal shifts, societal pressures, and past struggles as fueling the silent surge.
Eating disorders are quietly but steadily increasing among women in midlife and beyond.¬†
Doctors and specialists say they‚Äôve seen a noticeable uptick in women ages 40 to 70 seeking help for disordered eating. And because these women don‚Äôt fit the stereotype of a person with an eating disorder‚Äînamely, they‚Äôre not teenage girls‚Äîthey often experience missed diagnoses or delayed care.

entry.title: Why Noah‚Äôs Ark will never be found
entry.summary:
A painting of Noah‚Äôs Ark. The Old Testament tale has not only inspired countless generations of artists, but also more than a century of ‚Äúscientific‚Äù attempts to locate remains of the fabled vessel. For more than a century, people have sought the precise location of Noah‚Äôs Ark. Archaeologists say it‚Äôs a fool‚Äôs errand.
Noah‚Äôs Ark is among the best known and most captivating of all Old Testament stories. After creating humans, God¬†became so displeased with them¬†that he struck Earth with an all-encompassing flood to wipe them out.
But there was one noteworthy (and seaworthy) exception: the biblical patriarch and his family. Accompanied by pairs of each of the planet‚Äôs animals, all rode out the deluge in an enormous wooden vessel.

entry.title: U.S. or British‚Äîwhich set of Virgin Islands is right for you?
entry.summary:
The USVI and BVI are home to world-famous beaches, water sports, and the freshest seafood. Much like the United States and Britain, the USVI and BVI are similar but different in the most nuanced ways. Here are some tips for the traveler trying to determine where to land.
Boasting a sailing culture like no other, the Virgin Islands archipelago calls to travelers from all over the globe. Blue-green waves as clear as glass shimmer and dance, revealing a sprawling underwater ecosystem that weaves its way through caves, tunnels, shipwrecks, and reefs. Britain maintains governance over the eastern isles while the United States is responsible for¬†the west.
This split presents the modern traveler with a dilemma: USVI or BVI?¬†Read on to learn more about each, and discover which set of ‚Ä¶

entry.title: The legend of Area 51‚Äîand why it still fascinates us
entry.summary:
The myths surrounding Area 51 draw tourists from around the world, as people travel to the air base near Rachel, Nevada, in hopes to catch a glimpse of otherworldly spacecrafts.¬†
Although the legend of extraterrestrials at the top-secret facility has been discredited for years, some of the myths are based on true events. Here‚Äôs what you need to know about Area 51.¬†
Area 51 is one of the most famous military installations in the world‚Äîa remarkable feat considering the government didn‚Äôt formally acknowledge the site existed until 2013. Rumors of hidden extraterrestrial technology and lifeforms have fueled its popularity and the public‚Äôs imagination for decades.

entry.title: Your next adventure: Unwind in Hakone, just outside Tokyo
entry.summary:
Tokyo‚Äôs vibrant metropolis is a must-visit on any trip to Japan‚Äîbut just a short journey away is the town of Hakone, a serene escape where natural hot springs, mountain views, and tradition peacefully await. ‚ÄúTokyo is really the center of everything,‚Äù says National Geographic photographer Jonathan Irish. ‚ÄúBut Hakone is the opposite of that. It‚Äôs where people in Tokyo go to relax and recharge.‚Äù
Southwest of Tokyo and nestled in Kanagawa Prefecture‚Äîa regional jurisdiction somewhat similar to a state or province‚ÄîHakone offers a serene escape from city life. Known for its rejuvenating onsens (natural hot springs), historic teahouses, and breathtaking views of Mount Fuji, it has long been a favorite day-trip retreat for those seeking the traditional wellness remedies of the region. And, lu‚Ä¶

entry.title: Gaza: UN urges Israel to allow fuel into Strip
entry.summary: The crisis in Gaza is worsening, UN humanitarians warned on Monday, as ongoing hostilities and access restrictions drive displaced communities deeper into despair.

entry.title: Gaza: ‚ÄòUnbearable‚Äô suffering continues, UN official tells Security Council
entry.summary: The humanitarian crisis in Gaza is deepening at an alarming rate, a senior United Nations official warned on Monday, as Israeli military operations and attacks on civilians seeking aid continue to exact a devastating toll on lives and infrastructure.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Report reveals significant rise in civilian casualties and rights violations in Ukraine
entry.summary: Civilian casualties and violations in Ukraine have significantly escalated in recent months, including a sharp rise in often deadly drone attacks, the UN human rights office, OHCHR, said in a report published on Monday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Afghanistan: Surging returns from Iran overwhelm fragile support systems, UN agencies warn
entry.summary: More than 700,000 Afghan migrants have returned from Iran so far this year, including 256,000 in June alone, the UN International Organization for Migration (IOM) reported on Monday, warning of immense pressures on Afghanistan‚Äôs overstretched support systems.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Human rights can be a ‚Äòstrong lever for progress‚Äô in climate change, says UN rights chief
entry.summary: The UN‚Äôs top rights official on Monday urged the international community to confront the growing human rights implications of climate change.

entry.title: Every hour, 100 people die of loneliness-related causes, UN health agency reports
entry.summary: One in six people are affected by loneliness, with significant implications for health and well-being, according to a new report from the UN World Health Organization (WHO).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: After the big development pledges in Sevilla, UN says action starts now
entry.summary: Now the big promises have been formally adopted in the Spanish city of Seville to turbocharge financing for sustainable development, how are the ambitious goals going to be met ‚Äì and how quickly?

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: It‚Äôs time to finance our future and ‚Äòchange course‚Äô, Guterres tells world leaders in Sevilla
entry.summary: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre here in Sevilla to change course,‚Äù the UN chief told world leaders on Monday, calling on them to grasp a once-in-a-decade opportunity to close a $4 trillion financing gap facing developing countries to meet sustainable development goals ‚Äì and build a better world for all.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Funding shortages threaten relief for millions of Sudanese refugees: WFP
entry.summary: Critical shortfalls in global humanitarian funding now threaten millions of Sudanese refugees fleeing war to seek refuge in neighbouring countries, the UN World Food Programme (WFP) said on Monday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: This is the story behind the Great Compromise
entry.summary:
Tempers were fraying in the muggy chambers of Pennsylvania‚Äôs statehouse. Excluding Rhode Island, delegates from 12 states had been meeting in Philadelphia for seven weeks to reshape the young country‚Äôs Articles of Confederation into a new, more functional national constitution. The convention included some of the nation‚Äôs most respected leaders, including Gen. George Washington, 81-year-old Benjamin Franklin, Virginia legislator James Madison, and the young firebrand Alexander Hamilton. Many had served in the Continental Army; all were male, white, and prosperous landowners. Yet by July they were deadlocked over a key issue: how to allot power in the newly formed United States.
(He was a Founding Father. His son sided with the British.)
The argument came down to big states versus‚Ä¶

entry.title: This is what a meal looks like in Canada's Niagara wine country
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
‚ÄúI‚Äôm not really a farmer,‚Äù Renee Delaney tells me sheepishly, despite our surroundings clearly suggesting otherwise.
Nearby, a chorus of grunting piglets wallow in a mud bath, overlooked by a pen of miniature goats. ‚ÄúAll this started life 10 years ago with just one tomato plant, which I brought to put food on the table as a single mother,‚Äù says Renee. She gestures, with an arm covered in botanical tattoos, at her 19-acre plot at Small Scale Farms. An abundant tapestry of potato fields and vines bowing under the weight of juicy ripe tomatoes unfurls towards a distant red barn, which is home to the farm shop, painting a glorious picture of rural idyll.
Canada‚Äôs Niagara Region, in the province of Ontario, encompa‚Ä¶

entry.title: Investigating Cold Cases: How Two Journalists Dug Into Decades-Old Civil Rights Era Killings
entry.summary: To resurrect civil rights era cold cases, two reporters uncovered new sources and accessed forgotten government documents to reconsider the historical record.

entry.title: Register for Free Training Course: Digital Security for Journalists in Times of Crisis
entry.summary: The Global Investigative Journalism Network and the Knight Center for Journalism in the Americas are offering a new course for free focusing on digital security for journalists in times of crisis.

entry.title: Food halls are Europe's hottest culinary trend‚Äîhere's why
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
A culinary revolution is simmering in Europe. Despite the challenges of a global pandemic, the past eight years have seen the number of food halls across the continent double, completely reshaping the dining scene. Traditionally associated with the hawker centres of Southeast Asia, the trend of multiple vendors and a variety of cuisines under one roof has now reached more than 135 locations with more sites being sought every week.
For the vendor, food halls provide a platform to showcase their talent without the risks associated with opening a restaurant; for the consumer, a plethora of options at a more affordable price point. Authenticity, locality and sustainability are key factors for many potential visitors, ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Everything you need to know about Scottish whisky
entry.summary:
In Scotland, whiskey is produced in every corner of the country, and there are complex contrasts between them, from an eye-opening Islay whisky, a sweet sip from Speyside or the lighter lowland styles. Don‚Äôt like whisky? Then you haven‚Äôt properly explored Scotch. Scotland‚Äôs whisky-makers are masters of malts, offering more flavour variety, production prowess and heritage than anywhere else in the world. Here‚Äôs our ultimate guide, with Scottish drams to delight every drinker.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
These days, every nation is discovering whisky distillation, but the global superstars are without doubt the Scottish. With a production history dating back to the 15th century, the country has spent hundreds of years perfecting distillati‚Ä¶

entry.title: Beyond the beach, Antalya makes for a cultural city break
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Gateway to the Turkish Riviera, Antalya basks in the sunshine on the country‚Äôs southern Mediterranean coast, hugging the gulf that bears its name. Modern but with a picturesque, ancient heart, the city centres around a Roman-era harbour and the lattice of cobblestone lanes that make up the old town Kalei√ßi (meaning ‚Äòwithin the castle‚Äô), which is dotted with centuries-old mosques and restored Ottoman houses. It‚Äôs here that locals pause for long mezze lunches beneath waves of fuschia bougainvillea, or sit with an ice cream to soak up the sight of the Taurus Mountains rising in the distance beyond the bay.
Much like Rome, this is a city that wears its history on its sleeve, with stretches of two-thousand-year-old wall‚Ä¶

entry.title: LIVE: World leaders in Sevilla launch ambitious push to finance the future
entry.summary: From rising debt and shrinking investment, to the aid funding crisis and struggles to meet ambitious development goals, the global financial system is failing the people it's supposed to serve: that's the challenge facing world leaders gathered in Spain's sweltering southern jewel of Sevilla this week, as the ¬†UN's 4th International Conference on Financing for Development gets underway. Follow our live Meetings Coverage below; app users can catch all the action from the opening day here and you'll find all related stories on our special dedicated page right here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Faith in finance: Indonesia's innovative path to sustainable development
entry.summary: Indonesia has been putting its faith in innovative approaches to financing to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), the internationally agreed targets to end poverty, hunger and inequality, fight climate change and preserve the planet.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Tide of change in Philippines as women revive watersheds and livelihoods
entry.summary: In the coastal town of Sasmuan, Philippines, life flows with the river‚Äôs tide. At dawn, slender boats glide through calm waters as fishing nets are cast beneath the warming sky.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Guterres welcomes peace deal between DR Congo and Rwanda
entry.summary: UN Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres has welcomed the peace agreement between the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) and Rwanda signed on Friday in the United States capital, Washington, DC.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: ‚ÄòGlobal solidarity benefits us all‚Äô: Spain makes the case for development funding
entry.summary: Funding cuts to international development have cast a pall over a major UN-led international conference set to address the huge challenges faced by countries in the Global South. Despite this sobering backdrop, Eva Granados, Spanish Secretary of State for International Cooperation, insists that global solidarity is still alive, despite indications to the contrary.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Was Alexander the Great really poisoned?
entry.summary:
The sick Alexander (Alessandro infermo), by Domenico Induno, 19th Century, oil on canvas. Alexander drinks from a cup to show his trust in the doctor who gave it to him and condemns Parmenione who told him he would be poisoned. This event was said to take place in 333 B.C., 10 years prior to Alexander's death. The young conqueror fell suddenly and fatally ill at an all-night feast. Now, a Stanford historian has found a potential culprit.
In June 323 BCE, in the palace of King Nebuchadnezzar II in Babylon, the most powerful man in the world died. Just 13 days earlier, Alexander the Great‚Äîthe greatest conqueror the world had seen‚Äîhad been drinking at one of his many all-night banquets when he suddenly cried out in pain. He was sent to bed suffering from abdominal pain and a fever, an‚Ä¶

entry.title: These treasures changed what we thought about the Celts
entry.summary:
During the Iron Age (circa 1200-500 B.C.), a large swath of non-Mediterranean Europe was occupied by a people who became known for their craftsmanship, religion, and warfare. Different groups, now known collectively as Celts, spoke languages belonging to the Celtic family and shared a common ideological framework reflected in a series of divinities they worshipped in religious festivities.
The Romans built up a stereotype of the Celts and other enemies, like the Germanic peoples, as barbarians. They caricatured them as blond, white-skinned giants from the north with a primitive tendency for drunkenness and violence. This clicheÃÅ helped condition how researchers regarded the Celts. But in recent decades, new readings of the classical sources and some fascinating archaeological discover‚Ä¶

entry.title: Take a mouthwatering trip down Alabama‚Äôs Barbecue Trail
entry.summary:
Texas has brisket, Memphis has ribs. The Carolinas enjoy their pulled pork, and Kansas City is all about the sauce game. But not many immediately associate barbecue with Alabama. Well, except for one thing‚Äîthe mayonnaise-y white sauce.
While the state‚Äôs polarizing contribution to the American barbecue consciousness celebrates its 100th anniversary this year, there‚Äôs much more to the state‚Äôs barbecue than white sauce, and many Alabamians would proudly put their barbecue among the best in the country. With a mouthwatering Alabama Barbecue Trail‚Äîfrom civil rights hot spots to 100-year-old joints‚Äîthere‚Äôs no better way to uncover Alabama‚Äôs unique cuisine and history than biting into it.
Barbecue borrows the cooking methods of Native Americans, meats and sauces of European immigrants‚Ä¶

entry.title: What is colonialism?
entry.summary:
Christopher Columbus set sail from Spain in 1492. In recent years, the story of this journey has evolved from an exciting tale of exploration to an event marking the beginning of violence against Indigenous populations in North and South America. Colonizing Indigenous people‚Äîand exploiting their land and resources‚Äîhas a long and brutal history.
Merriam-Webster defines colonialism as ‚Äúcontrol by one power over a dependent area or people.‚Äù It occurs when one nation takes control of another for benefits such as resources. Often, they force their language and culture on the locals.
By 1914, Europeans had colonized a large majority of the world‚Äôs nations at some point. Japan, Korea, and Thailand are the only other nations Europeans never colonized.
Colonialism is closely relat‚Ä¶

entry.title: When climbing Mount Everest, what counts as cheating?
entry.summary:
In 1978, Austrian physician and mountaineer Oswald Oelz was a team doctor on an expedition to Mount Everest when climbers Reinhold Messner and Peter Habeler became the first people to reach its summit without supplemental oxygen. Before then, it was unthinkable that humans, unassisted, could climb 29,032 feet, the height of Everest, where due to drop in atmospheric pressure we inhale only about 30 percent of the oxygen we breath at sea level.
Almost half a century later, Oelz‚Äôs grand-nephew, Austrian climbing guide Lukas Furtenbach, was the architect of a new feat atop Mount Everest. This May, four of his clients, along with five Sherpas, summited the world‚Äôs tallest mountain only five days after they left London. Usually, it takes an average of 40 days of slow acclimatisation to adju‚Ä¶

entry.title: A Swiss village was buried under a mountain. This town could be next.
entry.summary:
In this aerial view, rubble and ice fill a portion of the Loetschental Valley following a landslide on June 3, 2025 in Blatten, Switzerland. Over 317 million cubic feet of rubble, mud, and ice fell on to Blatten on May 28. In the past century, scientists have observed more rockfalls and avalanches in the Alps, a looming threat to nearby villages.
Last month, Lukas Kalbermatten-Ritler stood in a hamlet overlooking the small Swiss village of Blatten opposite the Birch Glacier, holding up his camera phone up in disbelief.
‚ÄúIt was like a bomb went off,‚Äù says Kalbermatten-Ritler, who‚Äôs home and historic third-generation family-owned Hotel Edelweiss was destroyed on May 28. ‚ÄúThere were black rocks coming like a wall over the glacier, like it was a big hand taking the village. Th‚Ä¶

entry.title: Meet the Colombians shaking up Cartagena's cultural scene
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The roar of scooters battles with the beat of salsa and the bellows of market stallholders. Plantains blanket the ground, and corn-loaded carts criss-cross between people and rogue chickens. An¬†artist paints posters for the city‚Äôs upcoming festivals while a man sits in a plastic chair on the pavement and gets a haircut. This is Cartagena‚Äôs open-air Bazurto Market, and it‚Äôs a labyrinth of unfiltered chaos.
The market, a few miles outside the city centre, is full of Cartageneros like local chef Mar√≠a Cecilia Restrepo, simply known as Chechi, who come here to buy their fish, meat, fruit and vegetables. ‚ÄúThe smells, the colours, knowing where our food comes from: it all provides context to the cuisine of Cartagena,‚Äù sh‚Ä¶

entry.title: Video shows rare fireball meteor explode in broad daylight
entry.summary:
Illustration of a fireball passing in front of the moon as it crosses through Earth's atmosphere. Fireball meteors fall on the Earth every day but it's rare to see one in the daytime. Fireballs fall on the Earth every day‚Äîbut the one that just streaked across the southeastern U.S. this week was unlike the rest. Here‚Äôs why.
People across Georgia on Thursday witnessed an unusual flash of light streaking through the bright blue sky, followed by a thunderous boom that rattled windows. But there were no thunderstorms in the area. The culprit? An exceptionally bright meteor called a fireball.
Videos from dashcams and security cameras shared online caught the event, which occurred around 12:24 p.m. EDT on June 26. It was also observed by a lightning detector on the National Oceanic a‚Ä¶

entry.title: Syria: UN commission hails recent action to address past violations
entry.summary: The interim authorities in Syria have taken important steps in recent weeks to address past violations, the Chair of the Independent International Commission of Inquiry on the country said on Friday in an update to ¬†the UN Human Rights Council in Geneva.

entry.summary: The head of UN Peacekeeping affirmed the critical role played by the ‚Äúblue helmets‚Äù in Lebanon and Syria during a press conference at Headquarters in New York.

entry.summary: As the Foreign Ministers of Rwanda and the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) signed a draft peace agreement in Washington this Friday, tensions and violence continue to grip eastern DRC.

entry.title: New UN report charts path out of debt crisis threatening global development
entry.summary: A decade after the adoption of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), development is facing serious headwinds ‚Äì including what UN officials describe as a ‚Äúsilent crisis‚Äù of surging debt service payments in low-income countries.

entry.summary: Three years into the conflict in Sudan, the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) and Sudan Armed Forces (SAF) continue to pursue a military solution, violating international law and the rights of civilians in the process.

entry.title: Myanmar human rights crisis deepens as aid collapses, attacks intensify
entry.summary: Myanmar is spiralling deeper into humanitarian catastrophe, the UN‚Äôs top human rights official warned on Friday, as escalating military attacks, crippling aid restrictions and collapsing international support push millions toward starvation and despair.

entry.title: Short-range drone attacks deepen crisis on Ukrainian frontlines
entry.summary: Attacks with short-range drones killed at least 395 civilians and injured 2,635 between February 2022 ‚Äì the start of Russia‚Äôs full-scale invasion of Ukraine ‚Äì and April 2025, the UN Human Rights Monitoring Mission (HRMMU) reported on Thursday.

entry.title: Guterres calls for immediate Gaza ceasefire as humanitarian crisis reaches ‚Äòhorrific proportions‚Äô
entry.summary: UN Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres on Friday reiterated his call for an immediate ceasefire in Gaza, warning that the humanitarian crisis has reached ‚Äúhorrific proportions‚Äù and that the world must not let the suffering of Palestinians be overshadowed by other regional conflicts.

entry.title: Gaza: Health system crumbles amid growing desperation over food, fuel
entry.summary: The first delivery earlier this week of urgently needed medical goods to enter Gaza in months will provide scant relief to the enclave‚Äôs people, who continue to be shot and killed in their search for food, the UN World Health Organization (WHO) said on Friday.

entry.title: 8 stunning sights in the night sky this July
entry.summary:
One of the closest and brightest globular clusters visible from Earth, M22 contains hundreds of thousands of stars packed into a tight, elliptical shape about 10,000 light-years away. Get your binoculars ready for dark skies, elusive planets, and a sky show spanning the entire month.
Stargazers, get ready to take in some awe-inspiring sights. This month offers a parade of star clusters, meteors, and various planet sightings, including the difficult-to-spot dwarf planet Pluto. Here‚Äôs what to look for in the July night sky.
The globular cluster Messier 22 (M22) reaches its highest point in the sky around midnight local time, specifically for observers south of 46¬∞ N latitude, since M22‚Äôs position favors the Southern Hemisphere.

entry.title: A music lover‚Äôs guide to Tokyo
entry.summary:
A Cajun-style band performs on a street in Tokyo‚Äôs Koenji neighborhood. It‚Äôs just one of several places to experience the city‚Äôs eclectic music scene. From record stores to jazz cafes to karaoke, here are the best ways to keep up with everything this music-infused city has to offer.
If you're a record collector, a guitar nerd, a jazz head, a garage rocker, or a karaoke crooner, Tokyo is possibly the best place on the planet for music lovers. Before planning a trip to Japan's capital city, here's what you need to know about its diverse music scene for all types of musicophiles.
Ask anyone who has visited Tokyo about record shopping and they will all mention¬†Disk Union. The behemoth music retailer has been around since 1967 and has multiple stores across the city. In Shinjuku ‚Ä¶

entry.title: A roadrunner in your neighborhood? It's a growing possibility.
entry.summary:
About a decade ago, Mary Taylor Young and her husband were pulling into the driveway of their cabin, a property nestled at 6,700 feet, in southern Colorado. Suddenly, they saw a face that they weren‚Äôt expecting: a roadrunner, with its signature spiky head crest and baby blue coloring around the eyes.¬†
‚ÄúMy husband and I were both like, ‚ÄòOh, my God, what is a roadrunner doing here?‚Äô‚Äù Young, a biologist and nature writer, says. ‚Äú‚ÄòDude, you belong in the desert. What are you doing?‚Äô‚Äù
Young says it wasn‚Äôt unheard of to see roadrunners in and around the nearby town of Trinidad, Colorado, which sits at about 6,000 feet in the northernmost part of the roadrunner‚Äôs range in the state. However, she was surprised by this higher altitude sighting, something that‚Äôs becoming more common.¬† ‚Ä¶

entry.title: New tech could tell you when it's too dangerous to be outside
entry.summary:
Two people pick grapes in a vineyard near Fresno, California. Outdoor farm workers are on average 35 times more likely to experience heat-related illnesses than the general population. Illnesses caused by heat‚Äîdehydration, cramps, and even strokes‚Äîcan come on quickly and quietly. New, wearable technology could help alert wearers to lurking danger.
After 10 straight hours picking grapes on a scorching 105¬∞F day in Bakersfield, California, in 2004 53-year-old Asunci√≥n Valdivia collapsed and died, a victim of heat stroke.¬†¬†
Some 436 workers later died from environmental heat exposure between 2011 and 2021 in the United States, and Valdivia‚Äôs death became emblematic of this risk, inspiring a bill introduced in Congress in 2023 to create safer conditions for laborers who work in e‚Ä¶

entry.title: These 3 cities near Paris deserve more than a day trip
entry.summary:
Chantilly, Fontainebleau, and Versailes are normally tacked on as day trips from Paris, but these three destinations are worth more time. If they weren‚Äôt eclipsed by the City of Light, Versailles, Chantilly, and Fontainebleau would be pilgrimages in their own right. Here‚Äôs why they‚Äôre worth an overnight stay.
Paris lures millions of visitors every year, but day trips are a perennially popular diversion. The Chateau of Versailles, mind-blowing in its grandeur, has instant name recognition all over the world. The Chateau of Fontainebleau coddled eight centuries‚Äô worth of French monarchs, and its forest was where the world‚Äôs first-marked hiking trails were born. And Chantilly, equestrian epicenter renowned for its racetrack, is home to France‚Äôs most important antique art museum, after‚Ä¶

entry.title: In this Italian region, Alpine cultures collide
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Trentino is a province of collisions. Stitched to the forested underbelly of South Tyrol, just south of the Swiss and Austrian borders, its spruce forests and opalescent lakes are shadowed by the Dolomites: grey-pink shark‚Äôs teeth mountains formed when the African and European tectonic plates made impact some 60 million years ago.
For the ancient Romans, these were frontier lands, with the nearby Brenner Pass on the Austrian border serving as a gateway for peoples, languages and recipes from the other side of the Alps. Today, those influences can be felt in everything from the hearty stews served in Trentino‚Äôs timber-framed restaurants to the old German dialect spoken in its remote mountain enclaves.

entry.title: Where to sample Australia‚Äôs best rum‚Äîand its rich history
entry.summary:
During the 18th century,¬†England sought out remote locations to house prisoners as a solution to its overcrowded jails.¬†In 1788, England's¬†First Fleet¬†arrived in¬†the Eora nation‚Äînow known as Sydney,¬†Australia‚Äîwith¬†11 ships of convicts¬†and officers. For this long voyage, they packed two years‚Äô worth of food and four years‚Äô worth of rum.¬†
The nation was founded without any formal currency except¬†a limited supply of coins, because it was meant to be a convict colony. However, it soon became clear they would need more structure, so they put their bountiful supply of rum to practical use.¬†
Rum became intertwined with the history of Australia. It was the original currency, the spirit of rebellion, and a powerful political tool.¬†

entry.title: These are the best gin joints in all the world
entry.summary:
Gin distillers around the world offer gin-making classes, lessons, and tastings. From London to Wisconsin, one-day gin academies across the globe let the public brew their own spirits. You might not go home with a diploma‚Äîbut you will go home with the world‚Äôs rarest gin.
There's something hypnotic about watching gin transform before your eyes, especially when you've selected every botanical that goes into it. This is the allure of gin academies, where visitors don't just tour facilities and taste spirits‚Äîthey sit down to copper stills and shelves of botanicals, creating a bottle of gin themselves,
Typically one-day workshops, enthusiasts become distillers for a day. From London to Wisconsin, here‚Äôs where gin lovers can roll up their sleeves and try the ancient alchemy of disti‚Ä¶

entry.title: Faith Kipyegon falls short in attempt to break 4-minute mile
entry.summary:
Faith Kipyegon approaches the finish line in her attempt to become the first woman to run a mile in under four minutes. The Kenyan beat the current world record, but missed out on the mythic barrier by six seconds.
Faith Kipyegon ran the mile of her life today. And yet the 31-year-old Kenyan, the best female middle-distance runner of all time, failed to add a new line to the history books, by running six seconds shy of becoming the first woman to run one mile in under four minutes.
Surrounded by pacers, Kipyegon streaked around the track at Paris‚Äô Stade S√©bastien Charl√©ty in a time of 4:06.42. The blistering run was more than a second faster than the world record that she already owns. Still, the result meant that history would have to wait for another day.¬†

entry.title: Here‚Äôs why you should visit Vail in the summertime
entry.summary:
Summertime in Vail brings ideal weather for outdoor fun, from hiking and to river tubing and browsing farmers markets. Colorado‚Äôs largest ski resort has a lot to offer in the warmer months, including scenic gondola rides, music festivals, world-class art, and backcountry hiking trails‚Äîwithout the crowds.
Snow-dusted peaks flanking the Bavarian-style villages, perfect for a day of skiing. Ice skating in the heart of the squares. Cozy cafes and bars from which to enjoy a hot chocolate or hot toddy. These are likely the winter wonderland images that come to mind when you think of Vail. But, after the ski season winds down and the temperatures start to increase, this Colorado resort area makes a great‚Äîand less crowded‚Äîplace for a summer travel adventure.

entry.title: The most otherworldly, mysterious forms of lightning on Earth
entry.summary:
Our atmosphere is like one big electrical circuit: Thunderstorms are the batteries that charge it up, and lightning is the current flowing through it. On the ground we see evidence of this circuit when lightning cracks and strikes the ground, or when it lights up deep inside a thundercloud, but high above the clouds lies a secret electrical zoo full of sprites, elves, and jets.¬†
These fantastical terms refer to light displays called transient luminous events or TLEs that occur in Earth‚Äôs upper atmosphere during thunderstorms. ‚ÄúTLEs are mysterious, beautiful, and uniquely different from conventional lightning, yet they connect weather, space, and electricity in one dramatic moment. They occur high above the clouds, almost silently, and are invisible to most people‚Äîbut they reflect powe‚Ä¶

entry.title: This creature can 3D-print its own body parts
entry.summary:
The larvae of a bristle worm, saltwater worms with elaborate, hair-like structures. Bristle worms have protrusions that act like a 3D printer, helping us to understand how cells regenerate.
  Most people will never see a bristle worm in the wild, but according to a new study, the science derived from these bristly beasts may someday benefit you or someone you know.¬† Bristle worms‚Äîaka polychaetes‚Äî are saltwater worms with elaborate, hair-like structures; in some species, they allow the animals to paddle through the open ocean or ‚Äúwalk‚Äù across the seafloor.¬† ‚ÄúOne of the reasons that we‚Äôre interested in bristle worms is because they‚Äôre great models for regeneration biology,‚Äù says¬†Florian Raible, a molecular biologist at the University of Vienna in Austria. ‚ÄúSo, they ‚Ä¶

entry.title: What your noisy knees are trying to tell you
entry.summary:
Joint sounds like cracking and popping are often harmless‚Äîbut when paired with pain or stiffness, they may signal early arthritis. Experts say age isn‚Äôt the only factor‚Äîdiet, inflammation, and movement play a big role in how your joints hold up over time. From gas bubbles to worn cartilage, here‚Äôs what makes your joints pop‚Äîand how to know if it‚Äôs something to worry about.
Snap. Crackle. Pop. If your knees sound like a bowl of cereal every time you stand, you‚Äôre not alone.
‚ÄúThose cracking or popping sounds people hear are really common. We call it ‚Äòcrepitus‚Äô in the medical world and, most of the time, it‚Äôs just a normal part of joint mechanics,‚Äù says Mitchell McDowell, an orthopedic surgeon, osteopathic physician, and president of M Bone and Joint. ‚ÄúIt could be tiny gas bubble‚Ä¶

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: Pew Research Center conducted this study to understand how Americans voted in 2024 and how their turnout and vote choices differed from 2016 and 2020. For this analysis, we surveyed 8,942 U.S. citizens ages 18 and older who are members of the Center‚Äôs American Trends Panel (ATP). We verified their turnout in the five general [‚Ä¶] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals: Research team Jocelyn Kiley, Director, Political ResearchScott Keeter, Senior Survey AdvisorHannah Hartig, Senior ResearcherBaxter Oliphant, Senior ResearcherGabe Borelli, Research AssociateAndrew Daniller, Research AssociateAndy Cerda, Research AnalystJoseph Copeland, Research AnalystTed Van Green, Research AnalystShanay Gracia, Research Assistant Communications and editorial [‚Ä¶] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. Demographic profiles of Trump and Harris voters in 2024
entry.summary: The composition of Republican and Democratic voters in the United States has changed since the 2020 presidential election, and the shifts have been even larger since the 2016 contest. Donald Trump‚Äôs voters overall were more racially and ethnically diverse in 2024 than in his prior campaigns, reflecting gains among Hispanic, Black and Asian voters. Conversely, [‚Ä¶] The post 3. Demographic profiles of Trump and Harris voters in 2024 appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Voting patterns in the 2024 election
entry.summary: For the most part, voting patterns across demographic groups in the 2024 presidential election were not substantially different from the 2020 and 2016 elections. But Donald Trump‚Äôs gains among several key groups of voters proved decisive in his 2024 victory. To explore voting patterns among subgroups over time, refer to detailed tables. Hispanic voters were [‚Ä¶] The post 2. Voting patterns in the 2024 election appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. Voter turnout, 2020-2024
entry.summary: Because partisanship and voting preference are highly correlated ‚Äì and most adults stick with their preferred party over time ‚Äì voter turnout is often a key factor in understanding why there are changes in electoral outcomes year to year. In the 2024 presidential election, a higher share of Donald Trump‚Äôs 2020 voters than Joe Biden‚Äôs [‚Ä¶] The post 1. Voter turnout, 2020-2024 appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Behind Trump‚Äôs 2024 Victory, a More Racially and Ethnically Diverse Voter Coalition
entry.summary: Pew Research Center‚Äôs in-depth study of its survey respondents who voted in the 2024 election examines turnout, voting patterns and demographics. The post Behind Trump‚Äôs 2024 Victory, a More Racially and Ethnically Diverse Voter Coalition appeared first on Pew Research Center.
